<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_strict_:
```c
size_t
MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_strict_ (char *str)
{
#ifdef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  size_t res;
  bool broken;

  res = MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_ (str, &broken);
  if (broken)
  {
    res = 0;
    str[0] = 0;
  }
  return res;
#else  /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
  size_t r;
  size_t w;
  r = 0;
  w = 0;

  while (0 != str[r])
  {
    const char chr = str[r++];
    if ('%' == chr)
    {
      const char d1 = str[r++];
      if (0 == d1)
        return 0;
      else
      {
        const char d2 = str[r++];
        if (0 == d2)
          return 0;
        else
        {
          const int h = toxdigitvalue (d1);
          const int l = toxdigitvalue (d2);
          unsigned char out;
          if ((0 > h) || (0 > l))
            return 0;
          out =
            (unsigned char) (((uint8_t) (((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) h)) << 4))
                             | ((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) l)));
          str[w++] = (char) out;
        }
      }
    }
    else
      str[w++] = chr;
  }
  str[w] = 0;
  return w;
#endif /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
const char d2 = str[r++];
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The code first ensures the loop only starts if str[r] != '\0'. After reading '%', it reads d1 and immediately checks if d1 == '\0' and returns; only when d1 is non-zero does it read d2 = str[r++]. Thus d2 will be within the NUL-terminated string (or will read the terminating NUL), so the access does not go beyond the object bounds. The only way this could access out-of-bounds memory is if the caller provided a non‑NUL‑terminated or otherwise invalid buffer (which is a general precondition/undefined-behaviour issue, not a violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 as it applies to <string.h> functions).
